Spyglasses can be found in every natural generating chest and they give you a short summary of the block\item\mob you look at. It will help the players to get familiar with the game's features.

I dont think we should remove Mending from the trading list. 0.07% chance. this means that you will have to catch, on average, roughly 1,400 things before catching a mending book. less then 0.1% chance. its almost impossible to get a mending book from fishing. where else would we get mending books? think of this. if we remove mending books from the trading list, how would we get Mending? Fishing we can't, Strongholds we cant, Dungeons we cant, neither as a chest we cant, its literally impossible to get a mending book if we remove it. That's why we cant remove Mending, ITS IMPOSSIBLE TO FIND ONE WITHOUT TRADING.

I feel that a way to fix the brokenness of trading would be to make it so breaking a villager's POI doesn't reset the trade; instead, they will only reset their trades once a day if not trade with.

They should also give you better books based on your popularity with the village.
This. Mending suposed to be a late-game reward, not something you can trade for.

It's a terrible idea. I think maybe increasing the price to 64 emeralds would be a better compromise. It would still be as 'easy' to get, but also require a bit of work. Mending is end-game gear, and I think 64 emeralds would be fair considering this. Plus you'll be passively leveling up villagers as well.

I don't like the idea because it's already hard enough to get and on the fact of anvils, your gear gets more and more expensive to fix over time. This gets irritating. I spent over an hour trying to get a mending villager. This would be horrible

Yeah, but it should only be mobs that have blood so not skeletons, or other unded mobs.

I can only speak for myself but sometimes the world just feels too big. I want to be able to explore far enough, reach the deep ocean that goes on forever and I'll know "here is where the world ends". Or I can find the coastline and spend a few days circumnavigating the continent, mapping it all out, then frame all the maps and make a big huge map of the whole world mounted on the wall at my home base.

I'm not really sure how large such a world type could get. Because there are about 60-and-a-half Overworld biomes, and some are rather rare, it might be a fairly far distance from origin before just the right conditions came up for the rarest biomes in the game to generate. (A "Small Continent" variant world type might be made in which edge biomes are not considered when meeting the above conditions for world Completion.)

Players should not worry about whether this proposed world type would constrain their exploration. They are still free to explore in any direction they see fit, whether that's evenly in all directions or in a narrow ribbon along the Z-axis, the game doesn't care. It will generate biomes as needed wherever the players want to travel. So if the players want their Continent-to-be to be more or less circular, all they need to do is explore that way, assume it already will be circular, and the game will follow their lead. Or if they want a "Ringworld" or "Halo" style of continent they can do that too.

Optionally, map wrapping/wraparound in X, Z, or both directions might be allowed as an alternative to infinite surrounding ocean, though this might produce unnaturally straight edges along biomes along the boundaries between positive and negative.

Artifacts of world generation might include gaps of unexplored areas surrounded by explored areas. When the world is judged Complete, the game engine should know not to try to fill these areas in with coast and deep ocean. An algorithm might be needed to compute the "interior-ness" of an unexplored area to determine whether it should be allowed to generate more land biome (even when land biomes have been "turned off" for the world) or whether it will be okay to go ahead and generate an inland "great lake". Maybe there is a percentage chance for either?

Multiply player's current X and Z coordinates, take the log-10 of the absolute value, and divide by 100. This is the percentage chance of generating an inland "deep ocean" or "great lake".

So for XZ < +-100, it's 4%; XZ < +-1,000 it becomes 6%; XZ < +-10,000 it becomes 8%, and so on.
This is a great idea!
Sounds nice, although I feel like islands would spawn in the endless ocean around the 'continent'. Butttt that's probably way too hard to code

Sometimes the never ending sprawl of a minecraft world can be discouraging. I love continental world gen with big oceans. Feels more wordly and explorable. Id love this and know it would help aid people in objective based gameplay. Infinite can be dissorienting.

This world type could generate with dry-land biomes beginning to be replaced by Ocean and Deep Ocean biomes starting at 20,000 to 25,000 blocks away from 0,0 and increasing the odds of replacement the farther away you go. The chance of a biome being overridden by an Ocean biome would never go all the way to 100%, allowing for the rare isolated island far away from 0,0.

Go far enough away and you might allow for "Very Deep Oceans" to begin generating, where Water source blocks start generating below y=0 and as far deep as a two or three layers above Bedrock.

I feel like there's a problem because this world type still allows for multiple land masses. For the biomes, I think there should be two stages: land and sea. In land (the first stage) all non-aquatic biomes can generate. In sea (stage two), it generates all aquatic biomes, and it is where the ocean monument is required (mushroom fields are counted as aquatic). After both stages are complete, it then only generates deep cold ocean.

World height: 255
Sea level: 0

The problem with that is, the end mobs don't like the ender dragon, and are happy you killed it, hence the "Free the end" advancement you get when you kill it. So they WOULD let you walk away from it without consequence.

I agree with Robotics5 that you're freeing the End by killing the Dragon, but I like the idea of having an End invasion, whether they are motivated by the Dragon's death or not. This would be a great late-game challenge for players, and could give Jeb an opportunity to add /utilize the Camoflage function of Shulkers that he tried to add earlier on.

I can't seem to post my own comment, so I'll just add my thoughts here. Honestly, I don't expect Mojang to implement all of these ideas in 1.20, but if just one or two of them get in, I'd be very happy!

My main ideas are this:

Five new crops: Tomatoes, Cabbage, Rice, Corn, and Onions.

Five new types of tree fruits, which each fall a from a specific type of tree when cut down or grow as modules like to mangrove propagules: Bananas (Jungle trees), Oranges & Lemons (Oak trees), Figs (Savannah trees), Cherries (Cherry blossom trees).

One new type of fish: Calamari, which has a 60-70% chance of being dropped when killing a squid, and a 2% chance of being found when fishing.

The new types of food are as follows: Cheese, which is made either by putting a milk bucket in a crafting table or putting milk into a cauldron and letting it sit until it becomes a cheese block, which can then be crafted into 9 cheese.

Sushi (rice + any fish + dried kelp)

Sun dried tomatoes: Made by either putting tomatoes in a furnace or leaving them on a burning campfire.

I've only just scratched the surface with this post, but I hope Jeb, Lena and the team are intrigued enough to look into adding some of these ideas!
